thread.title: Books that changed me: Amanda Keller
thread.title_full: Books that changed me: Amanda Keller

author: canberratimes.com.au
title: Books that changed me: Amanda Keller
text:
Amanda Keller. 
Amanda Keller is a radio and television presenter in Sydney. Her new memoir Natural Born Keller: My Life and Other Palaver (Allen & Unwin) follows her from a teenage crush on Barry Manilow to parenthood, working on TV with Andrew Denton and beyond.
The Narrow Road to the Deep North 
Richard Flanagan
I kept hearing about this book, and I saw it in every bookshop I entered. I'd pick it up and put it down again. To be honest, it seemed like such hard emotional work. But I found its pull overwhelming, and I finally bought it on holidays in Europe. Not my normal holiday read. Yes, it is emotionally hard going, but this book still vibrates so vividly for me. It's so beautiful, tragic and moving. I can't recommend it highly enough.
Advertisement Bossy Pants 
Tina Fey
I've never been a reader of autobiographies … until this one. I loved how hilarious and smart it was. She came from a normal suburban (tragedy-free) upbringing – unusual, it seems, for comedians – and still became the sharpest, funniest tool in the shed. Since then I've really loved autobiographies by funny women ... Denise Scott, Amy Poehler, Judith Lucy.
Every cook book ever written
I buy them all, and  flick through them while I'm watching telly. I can't remember the last time I cooked from one of them, but like pornography for men, I look and dream.
Guess How Much I Love You
Sam McBratney and Anita Jeram
This is the one where the mummy bunny tries to explain to her baby bunny how much it is loved. I bought it when I was pregnant with my first son, and cried at the counter of the bookshop as I turned the pages. I read it to both my boys, and have never made it through once without tears.
